The Chief of Staff made the following reports in amplification-cation of the information contained in Cabinet War Room RecordsNos. 534 to 536 :-Of the 19 ships in the convoy attacked by a raider on the12th February, 10 were known to be safe, and hope was entertainedof two more.We had lost two merchant vessels to Focke Wulf aircraft, andtwo to E-boats.Attention was drawn to the importance of safeguarding the armaments convoy now on the way.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.3, The First Lord of the Admiralty reported that the AsakaMaru would arrive at Lisbon very shortly.It was explained that, in reply to the telegram sent to him afterthe meeting of the War Cabinet on the 10th February-(W.M. (41)15th Conclusions, Minute 5), Lord Halifax had said that he thoughtit would be unwise to make an approach to President Roosevelt onthe lines proposed; and that he doubted whether we should obtainmuch sympathy from the United States if a crisis arose from anattempt to control enemy exports. The Permanent Under-Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs said that, in a conversation with the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, the Dutch Minister had enquired whether ourreluctance to give a specific guarantee of the territorial integrity ofthe Netherlands East Indies was to be attributed to a desire to consult the United States before answering.The Prime Minister said that it was, in fact, important toobtain President Roosevelt's advice on the suggested plan for mutual Anglo-Dutch help in the event of Japanese aggression in theFar East. The point should be put to the President as soon as the lease-and-Lend Bill was out of the way.The War Cabinet approved the course proposed.United States ofAmerica.Financing of contracts.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 5thConclusions,Minute 4.)Comparativetaxation.6. The Prime Minister said that he had received a personal telegram from Lord Halifax stating that it was of the utmost importance that we should without delay hand over to America ourremaining financial resources in that country. We should have to resign ourselves to meeting American wishes. A few weeks ago hehad doubted the wisdom of this course; but he no longer did so,since it was clear that we should receive from America far morethan we could possibly give. He proposed, however, to send aprivate telegram to the President, asking him to ensure that oursecurities were not taken over at knock-down prices.The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that this matter con-cerned the direct investments owned in the United States by theInsurance Companies and such firms as Courtaulds. Unless the transaction was very carefully handled, we might lose large sums.Sir Walter Peacock and others were already in the United Statesendeavouring to arrange for an orderly liquidation. But there wasa fringe of people in America who hoped to make sums of moneyout of the transaction. Lord Halifax, Mr. Purvis, and Sir F.Phillips all held that we must do what was asked, and he feared thatwe had no alternative in the matter.In reply to a question by the Minister of Labour and NationalService, the Chancellor of the Exchequer said that the United states authorities had refused a suggestion that they should take over ourassets in the United States of America and administer them on thelines applied to enemy property.The War Cabinet were informed that the United StatesGovernment were considering imposing increased taxation.Mr. Hopkins had telegraphed for full details of our taxation.These would be sent to him. The fact that the Americans wereimposing additional taxation made it all the more necessary that weshould show that we were willing to make sacrifices.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements, - United States ofAmerica.consultation between Britishand Americandefence experts.7. (40) 167thConclusions,Minute 5.)10. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theFirst Lord of the Admiralty (W.P. (41) 33). The Memorandumrecounted the occasions on which the Spanish Government had shown laxity in applying against enemy submarines the generally accepted principles of International Law. Authority was asked forthe Navy to continue the chase of submarines into the territorial waters of Spanish Morocco, Tangier or the Canaries, but not of metropolitan Spain or the Balearics. The attack might not becontinued after the submarine had entered a Spanish port.The War Cabinet approved the issue of instructions on thelines proposed.Africa. 11. The Prime Minister informed the War Cabinet that ithad been thought desirable to postpone the Second Reading of theHouse of Commons Disqualification (Temporary Provisions) bill until that day week. The Attorney-General would open the Debate,and he would wind up. A White Paper would be presented toParliament explaining the present position.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Great George Street, S.W.1,February 20, 1941.
